name: sfchronicle
text: San Francisco is opening learning hubs for 800 children, offering academic support, and a semblance of normalcy. The hubs provide a safe space for families struggling without child care since schools shut down in mid-March because of the coronavirus. https://t.co/nwOmBWP9P9

name: sfchronicle
text: On Aug. 15, PG&E mistakenly told a Fresno County power plant to wind down. About 10 minutes later, grid managers called for rolling blackouts. https://t.co/ik3BNe1vJM

name: sfchronicle
text: The smoke-choked Bay Area last weekend suffered some of its worst air-quality days since officials started keeping track in 1999, and Wednesday will mark an unprecedented 30 consecutive days of Spare the Air alerts. https://t.co/ohEoA5I4sg

name: sfchronicle
text: Restaurateurs and industry advocates say that businesses will likely close this fall until there‚Äôs more government funding or the pandemic ends. Some closures will be temporary, but other restaurants will likely never reopen. https://t.co/21iGHIuiog

name: sfchronicle
text: BART is getting a $1.2 billion federal grant to help pay for more frequent trains in the Transbay Tube, even as the agency struggles with low ridership, plummeting revenue and an uncertain future because of the coronavirus pandemic. https://t.co/S83NPi7jxd

text: Based on the current population in juvenile hall, the annual cost to incarcerate a single youth could push past $2 million in San Francisco. https://t.co/0ki87vQx24
